message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: A causal test of the strength of weak ties
Paper Abstract: The authors analyzed data from multiple large-scale randomized experiments on LinkedIn’s People You May Know algorithm, which recommends new connections to LinkedIn members, to test the extent to which weak ties increased job mobility in the world’s largest professional social network. The experiments randomly varied the prevalence of weak ties in the networks of over 20 million people over a 5-year period, during which 2 billion new ties and 600,000 new jobs were created. The results provided experimental causal evidence supporting the strength of weak ties and suggested three revisions to the theory. First, the strength of weak ties was nonlinear. Statistical analysis found an inverted U-shaped relationship between tie strength and job transmission such that weaker ties increased job transmission but only to a point, after which there were diminishing marginal returns to tie weakness. Second, weak ties measured by interaction intensity and the number of mutual connections displayed varying effects. Moderately weak ties (measured by mutual connections) and the weakest ties (measured by interaction intensity) created the most job mobility. Third, the strength of weak ties varied by industry. Whereas weak ties increased job mobility in more digital industries, strong ties increased job mobility in less digital industries.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about LinkedIn:

## Overview

LinkedIn is an American business and employment-oriented social networking service.(no content)The platform is primarily used for professional networking and career development, as it allows jobseekers to post their CVs and employers to post their job listings.

## Key Features

The basic functionality of LinkedIn allows users to create profiles, which for employees typically consist of a curriculum vitae describing their work experience, education and training, skills, and a personal photo.(no content)The site also enables members to make "connections" to each other in an online social network which may represent real-world professional relationships.

Users can also:
- Search for potential candidates
- Find jobs, people and business opportunities recommended by someone in one's contact network
- Follow different companies

## History and Ownership

In 2002, LinkedIn was co-founded by Reid Hoffman, and several other co-founders, including Jean-Luc Vaillant, Allen Blue, and Konstantin Guericke.(no content)In June 2016, Microsoft announced that it would acquire LinkedIn for $196 a share, a total value of $26.2 billion, with the deal being completed on December 8, 2016.

## Scale

When Microsoft acquired LinkedIn in 2016 for $26.2B, it was the world's "largest social networking site focused on the working world" with more than 400 million registered users.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about LinkedIn:

## Overview

LinkedIn is an American business and employment-oriented social networking service.(no content)The platform is primarily used for professional networking and career development, as it allows jobseekers to post their CVs and employers to post their job listings.

## Key Features

The basic functionality of LinkedIn allows users to create profiles, which for employees typically consist of a curriculum vitae describing their work experience, education and training, skills, and a personal photo.(no content)The site also enables members to make "connections" to each other in an online social network which may represent real-world professional relationships.

Users can also:
- Search for potential candidates
- Find jobs, people and business opportunities recommended by someone in one's contact network
- Follow different companies

## History and Ownership

In 2002, LinkedIn was co-founded by Reid Hoffman, and several other co-founders, including Jean-Luc Vaillant, Allen Blue, and Konstantin Guericke.(no content)In June 2016, Microsoft announced that it would acquire LinkedIn for $196 a share, a total value of $26.2 billion, with the deal being completed on December 8, 2016.

## Scale

When Microsoft acquired LinkedIn in 2016 for $26.2B, it was the world's "largest social networking site focused on the working world" with more than 400 million registered users.

Web search results for query: "Randomized controlled experiment"

Links: [{"title":"Randomized controlled trial - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randomized_controlled_trial"},{"title":"Randomized experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randomized_experiment"},{"title":"Crossover study - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crossover_study"},{"title":"Clinical epidemiology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clinical_epidemiology"},{"title":"Cluster-randomised controlled trial - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cluster-randomised_controlled_trial"},{"title":"N-of-1 trial - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N_of_1_trial"},{"title":"Scientific control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controlled_experiment"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about randomized controlled experiments:

## Definition

A randomized controlled trial (RCT) is a type of scientific experiment designed to evaluate the efficacy or safety of an intervention by minimizing bias through the random allocation of participants to one or more comparison groups.

## How It Works

In the statistical theory of design of experiments, randomization involves randomly allocating the experimental units across the treatment groups. For example, if an experiment compares a new drug against a standard drug, then the patients should be allocated to either the new drug or to the standard drug control using randomization.

## Key Benefits

The randomness in the assignment of participants to treatments reduces selection bias and allocation bias, balancing both known and unknown prognostic factors, in the assignment of treatments. Additionally, randomization reduces bias by equalising other factors that have not been explicitly accounted for in the experimental design (according to the law of large numbers).

## Blinding

When no such generally accepted treatment is available, a placebo may be used in the control group so that participants are blinded, or not given information, about their treatment allocations.(no content)A well-blinded RCT is considered the gold standard for clinical trials.

## Applications and Significance

RCTs are employed in clinical research and also in other research areas, including many of the social sciences.(no content)A randomized controlled trial can provide compelling evidence that the study treatment causes an effect on human health.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Strength of weak ties"

Links: [{"title":"Interpersonal ties - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interpersonal_ties"},{"title":"Mark Granovetter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Granovetter"},{"title":"Consequential strangers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consequential_strangers"},{"title":"File:Weak-strong-ties.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Weak-strong-ties.svg"},{"title":"Simmelian tie - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simmelian_tie"},{"title":"Behavioral contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_contagion"},{"title":"Weak interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weak_force"},{"title":"Tie (engineering) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tie_beam"},{"title":"Strong link/weak link - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strong_link/weak_link"},{"title":"Cable tie - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zip_ties"}]

## Strength of Weak Ties

"Strength of Weak Ties" is a seminal paper published by Mark Granovetter in 1973. It is one of the most influential articles in social science, with more than 78,000 citations according to Google Scholar.

### Core Concept

The thesis is that weak ties—acquaintanceships that are not reinforced by many mutual friendships—are especially pivotal in the flow of information. More novel information flows to individuals through weak rather than strong ties because close friends tend to move in the same circles, so the information they receive overlaps considerably with what we already know, while acquaintances know people that we do not, and thus receive more novel information.

### Origins and Research

Granovetter interviewed dozens of people to find out how social networks are used to land new jobs and found that most jobs were found through "weak" acquaintances. In marketing, information science, or politics, weak ties enable reaching populations and audiences that are not accessible via strong ties.

### Impact

The concept has become a core idea in the field of social networks, and subsequent studies of social networks have shown that information, resources, and new connections—which confer social capital—are the province of weak ties in all arenas of life, not just employment.

Web search results for query: "Network tie strength"

Links: [{"title":"Interpersonal ties - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interpersonal_ties"},{"title":"Simmelian tie - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simmelian_tie"},{"title":"Weighted network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weighted_network"},{"title":"Mark Granovetter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Granovetter"},{"title":"Structural holes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structural_holes"},{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Betweenness centrality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Betweenness_centrality"},{"title":"Cable tie - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cable_tie"},{"title":"Social networking service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_networking_service"},{"title":"Tie rod - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tie-rod"}]

I've found comprehensive information about network tie strength. Here's what the search revealed:

## Definition

The "strength" of an interpersonal tie is a linear combination of the amount of time, the emotional intensity, the intimacy (or mutual confiding), and the reciprocal services which characterize each tie. More formally, tie strength is defined by the linear combination of time, emotional intensity, intimacy and reciprocity (i.e. mutuality).

## Weak vs. Strong Ties

Granovetter's paper "The Strength of Weak Ties" is one of the most influential articles in social science, with more than 78,000 citations according to Google Scholar, and its thesis is that weak ties—acquaintanceships that are not reinforced by many mutual friendships—are especially pivotal in the flow of information.(no content)Granovetter found that most jobs were found through "weak" acquaintances. Additionally, strong ties are associated with homophily, propinquity and transitivity, while weak ties are associated with bridges.

## Related Concepts

For a simmelian tie to exist, there must be three (a triad) or more of reciprocal strong ties in a group. A simmelian tie is seen as an even stronger tie than a regular strong tie.(no content)According to weak ties argument, the stronger the tie between two people is, the more likely their contacts will overlap so that they will have common ties with the same third parties. This implies that bridging ties are a potential source of novel ideas.

Links: [{"title":"Interpersonal ties - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interpersonal_ties"},{"title":"Simmelian tie - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simmelian_tie"},{"title":"Weighted network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weighted_network"},{"title":"Mark Granovetter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Granovetter"},{"title":"Structural holes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structural_holes"},{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Betweenness centrality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Betweenness_centrality"},{"title":"Cable tie - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cable_tie"},{"title":"Social networking service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_networking_service"},{"title":"Tie rod - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tie-rod"}]

I've found comprehensive information about network tie strength. Here's what the search revealed:

## Definition

The "strength" of an interpersonal tie is a linear combination of the amount of time, the emotional intensity, the intimacy (or mutual confiding), and the reciprocal services which characterize each tie. More formally, tie strength is defined by the linear combination of time, emotional intensity, intimacy and reciprocity (i.e. mutuality).

## Weak vs. Strong Ties

Granovetter's paper "The Strength of Weak Ties" is one of the most influential articles in social science, with more than 78,000 citations according to Google Scholar, and its thesis is that weak ties—acquaintanceships that are not reinforced by many mutual friendships—are especially pivotal in the flow of information.(no content)Granovetter found that most jobs were found through "weak" acquaintances. Additionally, strong ties are associated with homophily, propinquity and transitivity, while weak ties are associated with bridges.

## Related Concepts

For a simmelian tie to exist, there must be three (a triad) or more of reciprocal strong ties in a group. A simmelian tie is seen as an even stronger tie than a regular strong tie.(no content)According to weak ties argument, the stronger the tie between two people is, the more likely their contacts will overlap so that they will have common ties with the same third parties. This implies that bridging ties are a potential source of novel ideas.

Web search results for query: "Social networks structure"

Links: [{"title":"Social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network"},{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Social networking service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_networking_service"},{"title":"Social media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media"},{"title":"Social structure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_structure"},{"title":"List of social networking services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_social_networking_services"},{"title":"Social network (sociolinguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_(sociolinguistics)"},{"title":"Network society - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_society"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Wikipedia is a social networking site - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Wikipedia_is_a_social_networking_site"},{"title":"Cognitive social structures - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_social_structures"}]

I've performed a web search on social networks structure. Here are the key findings:

## Definition

A social network is a social structure consisting of a set of social actors (such as individuals or organizations), networks of dyadic ties, and other social interactions between actors.

## Basic Components

Networked structures are characterized in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and the ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them.(no content)Networks are often visualized through sociograms in which nodes are represented as points and ties are represented as lines.

## Key Structural Concepts

Social network analysis examines several important structural features:

- **Dyadic and Triadic Levels**: A dyad is a social relationship between two individuals, while a triad consists of three individuals.

- **Tie Strength**: Tie strength is defined by the linear combination of time, emotional intensity, intimacy and reciprocity, with strong ties associated with homophily, propinquity and transitivity, while weak ties are associated with bridges.

- **Structural Holes and Cohesion**: Structural holes are the absence of ties between two parts of a network, and finding and exploiting a structural hole can give an entrepreneur a competitive advantage.

- **Group Formations**: Groups are identified as 'cliques' if every individual is directly tied to every other individual, or as 'social circles' if there is less stringency of direct contact.

## Analysis Approach

An axiom of the social network approach to understanding social interaction is that social phenomena should be primarily conceived and investigated through the properties of relations between and within units, instead of the properties of these units themselves.

Web search results for query: "Job mobility career transitions"

Links: [{"title":"Labor mobility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labor_mobility"},{"title":"Career ladder - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Career_ladder"},{"title":"Transition Assistance Program - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transition_Assistance_Program"},{"title":"Job rotation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Job_rotation"},{"title":"Horizontal mobility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horizontal_mobility"},{"title":"Geographic mobility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geographic_mobility"},{"title":"Job Corps - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Job_Corps"},{"title":"School-to-work transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/School-to-work_transition"},{"title":"Mobility transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobility_transition"},{"title":"Global workforce - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_workforce"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about job mobility and career transitions:

## Overview

Labor or worker mobility is the geographical and occupational movement of workers. This encompasses various forms of career movement and transitions in the workplace.

## Types of Career Transitions

**Job Rotation:** Job rotation is the lateral transfer of employees between jobs in an organization without a change in their hierarchical rank or salary grade.(no content)The practice serves several functions including staffing, employee motivation, managing employee fatigue, employee orientation and placement, and career development.

**Career Ladder Progression:** In business and human resources management, the career ladder typically describes the progression from entry level positions to higher levels of pay, skill, responsibility, or authority.

**Horizontal Mobility:** Horizontal mobility occurs when a person changes their profession, but their social status remains unchanged. For example, if a doctor switches from a job in health care to teaching in medical school, the profession changes, but dignity and social status remain the same.

## Benefits and Challenges

**Benefits:** Job rotation provides employees with an opportunity to gain insights into the organization's diverse work and how their roles impact overall operations. By working across various roles and departments, employees develop a holistic understanding of the organization's processes, goals, and interdependencies.

**Challenges:** Job rotation is often associated with an initial temporary reduction in productivity, as employees undergo a learning curve while transitioning into new roles.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name, relation, entity_type, wikipedia_url, relevance

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! All tasks are complete. Here's a summary of what I did:

## Extraction Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution paper
- The paper conducts novel randomized experiments and proposes revisions to existing theory about the strength of weak ties.

**Extracted Triples (6 total):**

**USES relations (5 existing concepts/tools):**
1. **Interpersonal ties** (concept) - The foundational concept about weak vs. strong connections in social networks
2. **LinkedIn** (tool) - The empirical platform used for the large-scale experiments
3. **Labor mobility** (concept) - The outcome being measured in job transitions
4. **Social network** (concept) - The theoretical framework for analysis
5. **Randomized experiment** (method) - The experimental methodology used

**PROPOSES relations (1 novel finding):**
6. **Inverted U-shaped relationship** (concept) - The paper's key discovery that tie strength has a nonlinear (inverted U-shaped) relationship with job transmission

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and validation passed successfully.

Sources:
- [Interpersonal ties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interpersonal_ties)
- [LinkedIn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LinkedIn)
- [Labor mobility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labor_mobility)
- [Social network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network)
- [Randomized experiment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randomized_experiment)
- [Nonlinearity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinearity)
